definitions: stubbornly resisting control or discipline; willful and unpredictable
deviating from the expected path or course; following no clear direction
examples: The wayward teenager refused to follow the rules
Managing wayward employees requires patience and understanding
The wayward ball bounced into the neighbor's yard
A wayward breeze scattered the papers across the lawn

definitions: made less strong, powerful, or effective than before
examples: The weakened structure could no longer support the weight
His weakened immune system made him vulnerable to illness

definitions: gradually losing strength, power, or effectiveness over time
examples: The weakening storm finally moved out to sea
Her weakening grip on the rope worried the rescue team

definitions: in a manner showing little physical strength or energy
without confidence, enthusiasm, or determination; in a feeble way
examples: She smiled weakly after the exhausting surgery
The injured bird flapped its wings weakly
He weakly protested but knew they were right
She weakly defended her position during the debate

definitions: accustomed to managing without something previously relied upon or depended on
examples: The weaned calves were moved to a separate pasture
She was finally weaned off the pain medication

definitions: comfortable and practical enough to be worn; suitable as clothing or accessories
examples: The designer creates wearable art from recycled materials
These shoes are stylish yet wearable for everyday use

definitions: tiring or exhausting through continued use, activity, or strain
examples: The wearing journey left everyone exhausted
Constant complaints can be wearing on one's patience

definitions: feeling or showing extreme tiredness from exertion or strain
feeling bored or impatient with something experienced too often
examples: The weary travelers finally reached their destination
Her weary eyes showed she hadn't slept in days
He grew weary of the constant criticism
The public is weary of empty political promises

definitions: worn, aged, or damaged by long exposure to weather elements
having successfully endured difficult experiences or hardships over time
examples: The weathered barn stood against the stormy sky
His weathered face showed years of outdoor work
The company weathered the economic crisis successfully
Their weathered relationship grew stronger through challenges

definitions: having digits connected by a thin membrane of skin
examples: Ducks have webbed feet for efficient swimming
The frog's webbed toes help it move through water

definitions: joined in marriage; united as spouses
examples: The newly wed couple left for their honeymoon
They have been wed for over fifty years

definitions: joined together in marriage; united as husband and wife
strongly committed or devoted to a belief, cause, or practice
examples: The wedded couple celebrated their anniversary
They lived in wedded bliss for many years
He remained wedded to his outdated business methods
She was wedded to the idea despite opposition

definitions: forced or stuck tightly in a narrow space between objects
examples: The car was wedged between two trucks
A piece of food got wedged between his teeth

definitions: extremely small in size; tiny or little
examples: The wee kitten fit in her palm
We'll need just a wee bit of sugar

definitions: overgrown with unwanted plants; containing many weeds
thin, weak, and unhealthy in appearance; lacking strength
examples: The weedy garden needed immediate attention
The abandoned lot became weedy and overgrown
The weedy teenager struggled to lift the box
His weedy appearance concerned his parents

definitions: continuing or extending for the duration of a full week
examples: They planned a weeklong vacation to Hawaii
The weeklong conference attracted experts from around the world

definitions: crying or shedding tears, especially from sadness or grief
having branches that droop or hang down toward the ground
examples: The weeping mourners gathered at the funeral
She found him weeping quietly in his room
The weeping willow provided shade by the pond
Weeping cherry trees bloom beautifully in spring

definitions: having weight added to increase heaviness or provide balance
adjusted to give more importance or influence to certain factors
examples: The weighted blanket helped her sleep better
Divers use weighted belts to descend underwater
The weighted average considers more recent data heavily
Test scores are weighted differently in final grades

definitions: having no apparent weight, especially due to zero gravity conditions
examples: Astronauts experience weightless conditions in space
She felt weightless floating in the pool

definitions: having considerable weight; heavy and substantial in mass
having great seriousness, importance, or influence; requiring careful consideration
examples: The movers struggled with the weighty furniture
She carried a weighty bag of textbooks
The committee discussed weighty matters of policy
He faced a weighty decision about his career

definitions: showing warmth and friendliness to guests or new arrivals; hospitable
examples: The welcoming staff made guests feel at home
She gave him a welcoming smile at the door

definitions: moving or leading in a western direction; going toward the west
examples: The westbound train departed at noon
Traffic was heavy in the westbound lanes

definitions: coming from the western direction, especially referring to wind
situated toward or moving in the direction of the west
examples: Westerly winds brought cooler temperatures
The westerly breeze carried the scent of ocean
They followed a westerly course across the desert
The house has a westerly exposure

definitions: situated at the point farthest to the west of a region
examples: Hawaii is the westernmost state in America
They reached the westernmost point of the continent

definitions: located on or relating to the western side of a place
examples: The westside neighborhood has many new restaurants
She grew up in a westside apartment complex

definitions: moving, facing, or situated in the direction of the west
examples: The pioneers continued their westward journey
Birds began their westward migration in autumn

definitions: used for emphasis to mean 'at all' in negative statements
examples: There was no evidence whatsoever to support the claim
She had no interest whatsoever in the proposal

definitions: equipped with wheels for movement or transportation purposes
examples: The wheeled suitcase made travel much easier
Wheeled vehicles are not allowed on this path

definitions: playfully quaint or fanciful, especially in an amusing and imaginative way
examples: Her whimsical decorating style included fairy lights everywhere
The artist's whimsical sculptures made people smile

definitions: moving with great speed or force, especially of wind
used for or involved in beating or striking repeatedly
examples: The whipping wind tore branches from trees
Whipping rain made visibility nearly impossible
The whipping cream needed more time to thicken
He received a whipping punishment for his crimes

definitions: having long, stiff hairs growing from the face or snout
examples: The whiskered cat rubbed against her leg
The old whiskered gentleman stroked his beard thoughtfully

definitions: spoken in a very soft, quiet voice to avoid being overheard
examples: She heard whispered conversations in the library
The whispered secret spread quickly through the class

definitions: speaking in a very quiet voice, barely above a breath
producing soft, rustling sounds resembling quiet human speech
examples: The whispering students were told to be quiet
She was whispering instructions during the test
The whispering wind moved through the trees
We heard the whispering of waves on shore

definitions: covered with white paint or whitewash, especially on walls
deliberately concealed or glossed over unpleasant facts or wrongdoings
examples: The whitewashed cottage looked fresh and clean
They whitewashed the old fence last summer
The report was clearly whitewashed to hide failures
Critics accused them of whitewashed history

definitions: having a color that is nearly white; pale or off-white
examples: The sky had a whitish glow before sunrise
She noticed whitish spots on the plant leaves

definitions: relating to selling goods in large quantities at low prices
done on a large scale without discrimination; complete and extensive
examples: They buy wholesale products directly from manufacturers
The wholesale price is much lower than retail
The company made wholesale changes to its policies
Critics condemned the wholesale destruction of records

definitions: conducive to physical health and well-being; nutritious and beneficial
having a positive moral influence; promoting good values and behavior
examples: Children need wholesome meals for proper development
She prefers wholesome, organic food options
The movie provides wholesome family entertainment
He has a wholesome appearance and friendly manner

definitions: extraordinarily large in size, amount, or degree; huge
examples: They paid a whopping sum for the mansion
The meal came with a whopping portion of fries

definitions: arranged in a circular pattern around a central point like spokes
examples: The plant had whorled leaves around its stem
Scientists studied the whorled pattern of the shell

definitions: evil or morally wrong; characterized by deliberate cruelty or wrongdoing
playfully mischievous in a harmless way; showing spirited naughtiness
exceptionally good, skillful, or impressive in an informal sense
examples: The wicked witch cast an evil spell
His wicked deeds finally caught up with him
She gave him a wicked grin before pranking
The children played a wicked trick on their teacher
That guitarist has wicked skills on stage
She threw a wicked curveball in the game

definitions: having lost one's spouse through death and not remarried
examples: The widowed woman lived alone in the house
He became widowed at a relatively young age

definitions: undertaken or carried out without official authorization; risky and speculative
examples: The wildcat strike surprised company management
They invested in wildcat oil drilling ventures

definitions: done deliberately with stubborn determination; intentionally contrary or disobedient
examples: His wilful disregard of rules caused problems
The child's wilful behavior frustrated her parents

definitions: done deliberately with stubborn determination; intentionally contrary or disobedient
examples: Her willful violation of policy led to dismissal
The judge ruled it was willful negligence

definitions: skilled at using clever tricks to deceive or manipulate others
examples: The wily fox escaped from every trap
She used wily tactics to win the negotiation

definitions: lacking strength, courage, or determination; feeble and ineffectual
examples: His wimpy handshake made a poor impression
Don't be so wimpy about asking for help

definitions: having difficulty breathing normally, especially from physical exertion
examples: She was winded after climbing five flights
The winded runner stopped to catch his breath

definitions: following a twisting or spiral course with many turns and curves
examples: The winding road through mountains offered scenic views
They followed the winding path through the forest

definitions: exposed to or swept by strong winds; showing effects of wind exposure
examples: Her windswept hair framed her smiling face
The windswept plains stretched for miles

definitions: situated on or facing the side from which wind is blowing
examples: Ships anchored on the windward side of island
The windward slope receives more rainfall
